Ken,

Derek wrote:
> Hmm...why not?

To your response:
>Yes right, never connect into an input node.

I agree with Derek, why not?

I think Derek is coming from the point of view regarding "lateral inhibition" (LI), one of the
unique neural configurations occuring in biology.  I think it occurrs, for example, in the human
retina, or was that in the visual system of the crab in James Anderson's work?  Whichever!

I just remember the effect was to vastly reduce the input surface complexity when passing a signal
back to the ANN processing the sensory input.  It worked by having a single neuron within a
cluster of neurons "win" the activation and with its activation, inhibiting the adjacent neurons
on the cluster.  This facilitated edge detection, if I recall correctly.

I guess one possible additional distinction to make would be whether to disallow anything but
input neurons connecting to other input neurons as it seems this would be sufficient to implement
LI.

Perhaps you know of a mathmatical explanation identifying why connecting to input nodes is not
necessary within the NEAT framework.  Perhaps the desired effect(s) of LI are still achievable
within NEAT using the standard technique.


Derek,

Is this a pretty good re-representation of the idea LI?  And am I on the same track as you here? 
If I am not, what is your reasons for desiring connections back to the input nodes outside the
scope of LI?


Jim


--- Derek James <blue5432@...> wrote:
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green"
> > <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> > > 2) Can I assume that you do not allow connections
> > back *to* input 
> > > nodes? and that therefore the connections you
> > generate during 
> > > evolution ignore input nodes as possible targets?
> > 
> > Yes right, never connect into an input node.
> 
> Hmm...why not?
> 
> > Good luck with your project.   Don't be discouraged
> > if it's a bit of a
> > learning curve starting up.  I'm sure several here
> > can vouch that
> > after the initial framework gets put in place things
> > get easier and 
> > more interesting.
> 
> Yeah. :)  Philip and I have been working on our
> implementation for quite a while now.  We've learned a
> lot in the meantime, but it's taken quite a bit of
> effort, even though we built it on top of an existing
> opensource neural network engine and an opensource GA
> framework.
> 
> We had to ask quite a few questions along the way...as
> Ken said, hopefully this list will make it easier for
> people who are undertaking their own implementations.
> 
> Derek
